elements.name: Survey8 Introduction
elements.html:
Welcome to the Military Triage Delegation Experiment. Here you will have the chance to review the decisions of other medical professionals in difficult triage scenarios to assess whether you would delegate a triage situation in the future to those decision makers.

Each scenario is presented followed by how three different medics carried out their assessment and treatment separately for that situation. Their actions are listed in the order they performed them.

Each medic vignette is then followed by a few questions to assess how you perceived the medic’s decision-making style.

While you work your way through each vignette imagine you have seen a lot of other observations of this medic, and the behavior you see here is typical for how they behave.

Some of the scenarios will seem familiar to you. Please note that there may be differences in the details of the situation you saw and the one you will be evaluating. Specifically, please pay careful attention to what information is revealed to the decision maker, and consider their actions only with respect to the information they were given. Do not consider any information from your experience that might be different or contradictory.

The survey should take about 30 minutes to complete. Thank you for your participation.

elements.name: Note
elements.html:
Note that in some scenarios, there are buttons that expand/select the information for the medic and the patients.

Note that you can hit the "previous" button if you want to go back to any part of the survey.

elements.name: Medic-K82
options: Move to treat the casualty now
elements.scenarioDescription: Imagine that you are deployed as a military medic in a foreign country. You are the only medic with your unit. It will be at least 30 minutes before any casualty can be evacuated.

rows.probe_unstructured:
Your platoon is patrolling dismounted when your point squad encounters what seems to be an observation post and sustains one casualty. Your squad exchanged fire. Three enemy troops are reported fleeing the location. You have not received any additional fire in the last 2 minutes.
The casualty is in a location with cover, but you would need to move across 20 ft of exposed area to reach them. They are not visible from your location. They are a warfighter in the same military unit as you.
You are currently in a location with cover. Do you move to treat the casualty now, or wait in your current location?

Your platoon is patrolling dismounted when your point squad encounters what seems to be an observation post and sustains one casualty. Your squad exchanged fire. You have not received any additional fire in the last 2 minutes.
The casualty is in an exposed location and you would need to move across 100 ft of exposed area to reach them. They are bleeding heavily. They are a warfighter in the same military unit as you.
You are currently in a location with cover. Do you move to treat the casualty now, or wait in your current location?

Your platoon is patrolling dismounted when your point squad encounters what seems to be an observation post and sustains one casualty. Your squad exchanged fire. You have not received any additional fire in the last 2 minutes.
The casualty is in an exposed location and you would need to move across 100 ft of exposed area to reach them. They may have a broken leg. They are a warfighter in the same military unit as you.
You are currently in a location with cover. Do you move to treat the casualty now, or wait in your current location?

elements.name: Medic-K88
elements.scenarioDescription: Imagine that you are deployed as a military medic in a foreign country. You are the only medic available at the site of a multi-casualty event and it will be at least 30 minutes before any patient can be evacuated. There are two patients, Patient A and Patient B, and you only have time to treat one of them.

rows.probe_unstructured:
Patient A has a chest wound and is gasping for breath. They are a foreign civilian with no ties to the military.
Patient B has a dislocated left knee with no bleeding. They are a warfighter in the same military unit as you.
Which patient do you treat?

Patient A has a chest wound and is gasping for breath. They are a foreign civilian contractor who has been working with your unit.
Patient B has moderate bleeding from their left hip. They are a warfighter in the same military unit as you.
Which patient do you treat?

Patient A has started showing signs of compensated shock (high heart rate, fast breathing). Their bleeding was stopped after a large blood loss. They are a foreign civilian who used to be a member of the opponent military.
Patient B has moderate bleeding from their left bicep. They are a warfighter in the same military unit as you.
Which patient do you treat?

The casualty is in an exposed location and you would need to move across 100 ft of exposed area to reach them. They are not visible from your location, but you are told they aren't breathing. They are a US warfighter from a different branch of the military than you.
You are currently in a location with cover. Do you move to treat the casualty now, or wait in your current location?

rows.choice: Move to treat the casualty now
rows.probe_unstructured:
Your unit is conducting a mounted patrol on JLTVs when you are ambushed, receiving small arms and RPG fire, and sustaining one casualty. Your unit returns fire at the suspected enemy location. About six enemy troops are spotted withdrawing. You have not received any additional fire in the last 3 minutes.
The casualty is in a location with cover, but you would need to move across 20 ft of exposed area to reach them. They are not visible from your location, but you are told they aren't breathing. They are a foreign civilian with no ties to the military.
You are currently in a location with cover. Do you move to treat the casualty now, or wait in your current location?

rows.probe_unstructured:
Your squad is patrolling dismounted when it receives fire from a sniper and sustains one casualty. Your unit does not have a good idea of the suspected sniper location. You have not received any additional fire in the last 5 minutes.
The casualty is in a location with cover, but you would need to move across 100 ft of exposed area to reach them. They are screaming, but you can't see their injury. They are a foreign civilian with no ties to the military.
You are currently in a location with cover. Do you move to treat the casualty now, or wait in your current location?
